Justice.prompt: What movements will you connect with to help end white supremacy?

self.choice: Movement for Black Lives chapters around the country, on social media.

society.choice: Movement for reparations, for descendants of enslaved and exploited peoples.

sustainability.choice: Frontline environmental justice organizations led by Black women.

Justice.prompt: The communities most impacted by the climate crisis contribute to the problem the least. Who will you help raise funds for?

self.choice: Your own neighborhood, so it is prepared for a weather emergency.

society.choice: Cancer Alley in Louisiana, which faces hurricanes and pollution.

sustainability.choice: Housing projects without air conditioning, which are facing increasing heat.

Equity.prompt: How will you support Black communities in their fight for the basic rights of all people?

self.choice: Vote to make your voice heard.

society.choice: Protect voting rights by calling your representatives.

sustainability.choice: Work on the election campaigns of Black candidates.

Equity.prompt: Black homeowners are less likely to have solar panels on their homes. We need energy justice!

self.choice: Get a grant for solar panels on your rooftop.

society.choice: Start a solar cooperative with your neighbors.

sustainability.choice: Work on Justice40 campaigns, so 40 percent of energy investments go to underserved communities.

Health.prompt: Honor your breath, the breath of all people, and the air itself as a way to center in health.

self.choice: Take 5 minutes to deeply breathe some fresh air and meditate.

society.choice: Learn CPR to help people breathe.

sustainability.choice: Attend a Black Lives Matter protest to demand that everyone can breathe freely.

Health.prompt: Take steps to protect yourself, others, and the natural world from pandemics.

self.choice: Get the coronavirus vaccine.

society.choice: Call Congress to ask for Medicare For All.

sustainability.choice: Protest the destruction of forests.

Education.prompt: The American education system still does not provide equal education for all. How will you help improve it?

self.choice: Read The 1619 Project to educate yourself.

society.choice: Organize a school strike for equity in funding.

sustainability.choice: Plan to run for school board.

Education.prompt: Climate denial lessons written by the fossil fuel industry are being taught in schools. What will you learn about and share?

self.choice: False advertising techniques.

society.choice: Information that debunks climate lies.

sustainability.choice: The tactics of misinformation, so people can recognize it in many different contexts.

Education.prompt: Angry parents have been attending school board meetings to protest student climate strikes. How would you respond peacefully?

self.choice: Join the students on their strike.

society.choice: Speak about climate at the school board meeting.

sustainability.choice: Support virtual strikes that reduce fossil fuel use.

Housing.prompt: The racial wealth gap is huge, and largely exists because of unfair housing practices in the past. Which of these will you learn about and share?

self.choice: Redlining, where Black neighborhoods were not allowed to obtain loans for home purchases.

society.choice: Discriminatory and illegal housing practices that still exist.

sustainability.choice: Connections between air pollution and housing discrimination.

Housing.prompt: You are writing a utopian short story, in which the problem of affordable housing is solved. What is your ideal solution?

self.choice: Expanded public housing, guaranteed for everyone.

society.choice: Tiny houses for anyone falling on hard times.

sustainability.choice: Community scale solar power and weatherization in all residences, to lower maintenance costs.

Food.prompt: How will you help honor the land and water in which our food grows?

self.choice: Eat more plant based meals.

society.choice: Volunteer in a community garden that grows free fresh food.

sustainability.choice: Support small farmers that grow sustainably.

Food.prompt: Food waste is rampant in the United States. Can we make use of it before it spoils?

self.choice: Dumpster dive behind a grocery store to see what you can find.

society.choice: Build partnerships between grocery stores and mutual aid groups.

sustainability.choice: Support movements to standardize best by dates on food.

Community.prompt: We can take responsibility for our own parts of the world on a local level. How will you think global, and act local?

self.choice: Get to know your neighborhood by walking and biking around.

society.choice: Plan a block party to celebrate with your neighbors.

sustainability.choice: Organize a community meeting to listen to the needs and concerns of your neighbors.

Community.prompt: Local responsibility adds up, contributing to global improvements.

self.choice: Beautify the outdoor space around where you live.

society.choice: Participate in neighborhood cleanup events.

sustainability.choice: Get your hands dirty by helping out at a community garden.

Work.prompt: Work is about the contribution you can make, not just the paycheck you receive. Which of these could you commit to do?

self.choice: Choosing a career that marries your skills with community needs.

society.choice: Accepting a position of leadership in your democratic labor union.

sustainability.choice: Working for a climate justice nonprofit.

Work.prompt: Workers at your company have not gotten a raise in years. How can you prevent all the profit from being captured by those at the top?

self.choice: Ask your boss for a raise for yourself, and for others in your division.

society.choice: Share information about executive pay compared with workers.

sustainability.choice: Take your concerns to labor union organizers.

Energy.prompt: What action will you take towards universal access to clean, sustainable power?

self.choice: Read about solar cooperatives in Puerto Rico and Hawaii.

society.choice: Avoid using energy during peak demand times.

sustainability.choice: Put up a clothes line for the ultimate solar clothes dryer.

Energy.prompt: How do we make sure electricity is for people instead of profit?

self.choice: Find out how much money your building would save by putting solar panels on the roof.

society.choice: Start a solar cooperative in your neighborhood.

sustainability.choice: Work on a public power campaign, to transform a profit focused utility into one for public benefit.

Mutual Aid.prompt: Items are often designed to break, so people will buy more frequently. How can you help??

self.choice: Look up an online video to repair a broken object or appliance.

society.choice: Establish a community Fix It Yourself Clinic in your area.

sustainability.choice: Call your legislature about right to repair laws.

Mutual Aid.prompt: A big hurricane just hit the coast! Mutual aid networks can get help to those who need it most.

self.choice: Connect with mutual aid networks in your community.

society.choice: Send money to mutual aid groups in the disaster area.

sustainability.choice: Start a canned food and clothing drive to send to those most affected.

Just Migration.prompt: How can you help wealthy nations welcome those who have been displaced from their homes due to inequities?

self.choice: Invite your friends to watch a film about a migrant's journey.

society.choice: Advocate for migrant rights to your government.

sustainability.choice: Connect with organizations working on environmental justice for migrant communities.

Just Migration.prompt: In 2020, a record 55 million people were forced to move within their countries due to extreme weather events. What will you learn about and share?

self.choice: Arts and cuisine of affected countries.

society.choice: The history of Hurricane Katrina.

sustainability.choice: Loss and Damage, to repair for the destruction already being wreaked by the climate crisis.

Nature.prompt: Can you find a way to speak for the trees?

self.choice: Observe seasonal changes from under your favorite tree.

society.choice: Call local officials to deny permits for logging.

sustainability.choice: Tell your senator to pass the Civilian Climate Corps so former loggers can work on restoring ecosystems.

Nature.prompt: How can you appreciate nature today?

self.choice: Observe the cycle of the moon.

society.choice: Watch bird behavior with other bird lovers.

sustainability.choice: Research the wisdom of the ancestors about how humans are connected to Earth.

Recreation.prompt: Humans need rest and play. What will you do for yourself or others?

self.choice: Improve your musical skills by practicing an instrument.

society.choice: Tell your local officials to budget for public arts programs.

sustainability.choice: Call your representative about investment in high speed train systems.

Recreation.prompt: Recreation time in the outdoors does not have to be extractive, expensive or exclusive. How will you spend spring break?

self.choice: Working on an international volunteer project.

society.choice: Assisting urban youth on a trip to a national park.

sustainability.choice: Contributing to backcountry trail maintenance.

Environment.prompt: How will you help grow plants in your surroundings?

self.choice: Adopt some plants for a more restful home.

society.choice: Ensure public green space is built and maintained.

sustainability.choice: Work in your yard or a community garden, planting food or flowers.

Environment.prompt: All living beings need food, water, shelter, and space. How will you transform your environment?

self.choice: Create shade in an outside space.

society.choice: Work on establishing a habitat in a local schoolyard.

sustainability.choice: Pick up trash in your neighborhood park.

Decolonization.prompt: Systems created in colonized lands are based on the privilege and worldview of the oppressor, forming the basis of inequity.

self.choice: Pay a land tax to local Indigenous people.

society.choice: Help fund and promote a land trust for local Indigenous people.

sustainability.choice: Promote adoption of traditional ecological knowledge on all public lands.

Decolonization.prompt: Your government is planning a military campaign against a sovereign country, which it has no right to invade. How will you protest?

self.choice: By putting signs up in your windows.

society.choice: By learning and teaching about the culture of the country where the action is taking place.

sustainability.choice: With demilitarization movements, which seek to cut the budget of the entire military.

Storytelling.prompt: Humans have always learned about the world through stories shared. How will you help spread stories that reflect the truth of our full diversity?

self.choice: Tell your unique personal story, through art, song, or some other expression.

society.choice: Seek out stories from friends and strangers. Listen and share them.

sustainability.choice: Create a community to amplify underrepresented voices, including stories from nature.

Storytelling.prompt: How will you learn and share the stories of others, both near and far?

self.choice: Imagine being in the shoes of another person to understand their perspective and how they might feel.

society.choice: Participate in a community storytelling event or a poetry slam.

sustainability.choice: Attend your neighborhood environmental justice film festival.

Transport.prompt: You are ready to think beyond the electric car for clean transportation. What do you encourage your friends to do?

self.choice: Buy a two-seat electric scooter.

society.choice: Consider a career in public transportation.

sustainability.choice: Live close to public transportation in a walkable, bikeable city.

Transport.prompt: Everyone is dependent on transportation, so clean and equitable methods must be accessible to all. What will you do?

self.choice: Fix up an old bike that you bought at a yard sale.

society.choice: Try to get your city council to convert a four lane road into a boulevard with walking space.

sustainability.choice: Write a letter to the editor about replacing the diesel bus fleet with electric buses.

Arts.prompt: Human creativity and expression are a source of joy, beauty, social commentary, and ingenuity. How will you support the arts?

self.choice: Create an arts and crafts project using ecofriendly materials.

society.choice: Contribute to a student made video game that communicates about the Green New Deal.

sustainability.choice: Contact local officials to maintain a public arts budget for youth in low income areas.

Arts.prompt: Music can give us inspiration and strength to keep up our struggle for climate justice! How will you spread the vibes?

self.choice: Find some climate justice songs and learn the words. Sing it loud!

society.choice: Rewrite some traditional melodies to have lyrics about the Green New Deal.

sustainability.choice: Support a crowdfunding campaign for a local rapper to make a climate justice track and video.

Resources.prompt: Fixing and reusing may take time, but it saves on energy and resources that come with dismantling and recycling. What will you help to repair?

self.choice: Mend the small hole in your favorite socks. A stitch in time saves 9!

society.choice: Volunteer to help fix the gate at your local school.

sustainability.choice: Participate in a wetlands restoration project in your county.

Resources.prompt: We throw away 300 million tons of plastic each year, nearly equivalent to the weight of the human population. How can you help the world to quit plastics?

self.choice: Choose to refuse single use plastics.

society.choice: Become a citizen scientist and investigate plastic pollution in rivers and oceans.

sustainability.choice: Support residents in their fight against the construction of a new plastics plant.

Truth.prompt: How will you strive to tell and demand the truth?

self.choice: Learn about white supremacy and American exceptionalism, and the harm they have caused.

society.choice: Organize an event where people share their stories about overcoming oppression.

sustainability.choice: Integrate a truth and reconciliation process for climate justice, centered in schools.

Truth.prompt: Journalism is going through tough times. What can you do to support those who report the truth?

self.choice: Get educated about disinformation campaigns.

society.choice: Support a national environmental investigative journalism project.

sustainability.choice: Help to fund reporters who are covering local government.

self.choice: Join a group meditation practice.

society.choice: Join a Threshold Choir to help families and the dying through the passing.

sustainability.choice: Promote laws for low resource burial or cremation.
